''Xerula radicata'', commonly known as the '''deep root mushroom''' or the '''rooting shank''', is a widespread [[Agaric]] readily identified by its deeply rooted stalk ([[stipe (mycology)|stipe]]). It is synonymous with ''Oudemansiella radicata''.

== Description ==
The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is medium to large, flat, grayish or yellowish brown and streaked, with a central hump and has a size of between 5-12.5 cm. The surface of the cap is sticky or slimy when moist, with the underside displaying wide white gills, or [[Lamella (mycology)|Lamella]]. The brittle [[stipe (mycology)|stalk]] tapers at both ends and is nearly white above to brown below the soil.<ref>McKnight, Kent H. and McKnight, Vera B.(1987) ''A Field Guide to Mushrooms North America''. New York, NY: Houston Mifflin Company</ref>

The stem grows into a long deeply rooting tap root until it touches a piece of wood. This may grow up to 20 cm in length in some specimens.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Mushrooms-Fungi-Pocket-Spotters-Geoffrey/dp/1903954800|title=Mushrooms and Fungi|last=Kibby|first=Geoffrey|date=2004-04-20|publisher=Chrysalis Children's Books|isbn=9781903954805|location=London|language=English}}</ref>

== Similar species ==
Similar to ''Oudemansiella longipes''.
